HED Web Tools â€” User GuideÂ¶

OverviewÂ¶

HED Web Tools is a comprehensive web-based application for working with HED (Hierarchical Event Descriptors) data. This guide provides complete instructions for setting up, configuring, and deploying the application in various environments.

Note

This guide covers both development and production setups. Choose the section that matches your use case.

Table of ContentsÂ¶

Quick Start OptionsÂ¶

Choose the setup method that best fits your needs:

ğŸš€ Local Development SetupÂ¶

Best for: Trying out the application, contributing to development, or testing

Time required: ~5 minutes

Prerequisites: Python 3.10+, Git

ğŸ³ Production Docker DeploymentÂ¶

Best for: Production servers with Docker support

Time required: ~10 minutes

Prerequisites: Ubuntu Server, Docker, sudo access

ğŸ“š Documentation DevelopmentÂ¶

Best for: Contributing to documentation or building docs locally

Time required: ~3 minutes

Prerequisites: Python 3.10+

Local Development SetupÂ¶

PrerequisitesÂ¶

Ensure you have the following installed:

  • Python 3.10 or higher â€” Download Python

  • Git â€” Download Git

  • Command line access (Terminal, Command Prompt, or PowerShell)

Tip

On Windows, we recommend using PowerShell or the Windows Terminal for better command line experience.

Installation StepsÂ¶

1. Clone the RepositoryÂ¶

git clone https://github.com/hed-standard/hed-web
cd hed-web

2. Create Virtual EnvironmentÂ¶

Using a virtual environment isolates dependencies and prevents conflicts:

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv .venv

3. Activate Virtual EnvironmentÂ¶

Windows (PowerShell/Command Prompt):

.venv\Scripts\activate

macOS/Linux:

source .venv/bin/activate

Note

Youâ€™ll need to activate the virtual environment every time you work on the project in a new terminal session.

4. Install DependenciesÂ¶

pip install -r requirements.txt

5. Create Configuration FileÂ¶

Windows:

copy config_template.py config.py

macOS/Linux:

cp config_template.py config.py

6. Run the ApplicationÂ¶

hedweb --host 127.0.0.1 --port 5000 --debug

7. Access the ApplicationÂ¶

Open your browser and navigate to: http://127.0.0.1:5000

Note

ğŸ‰ Success! The HED Web Tools application is now running locally.

Development WorkflowÂ¶

Once you have the application running:

  1. Make changes to the code

  2. Restart the server (Ctrl+C, then run hedweb again)

  3. Refresh your browser to see changes

  4. Run tests before committing (see Testing section)

Documentation DevelopmentÂ¶

Setting Up Documentation EnvironmentÂ¶

1. Install Documentation DependenciesÂ¶

pip install sphinx furo myst-parser

2. Build DocumentationÂ¶

cd docs
sphinx-build -b html . _build/html

3. Serve Documentation LocallyÂ¶

# Install live server (optional)
pip install sphinx-autobuild

# Serve with auto-reload
sphinx-autobuild . _build/html --open-browser

The documentation will be available at http://localhost:8000 and will automatically rebuild when you make changes.

Documentation StructureÂ¶

docs/
â”œâ”€â”€ conf.py              # Sphinx configuration
â”œâ”€â”€ index.rst            # Main documentation index
â”œâ”€â”€ introduction.md      # Introduction to HED
â”œâ”€â”€ user_guide.md        # This file
â””â”€â”€ api/                 # API documentation
    â”œâ”€â”€ index.md
    â”œâ”€â”€ architecture.md
    â””â”€â”€ ...

Production DeploymentÂ¶

Docker Deployment (Recommended)Â¶

This method uses Docker for containerization and is suitable for most production environments.

PrerequisitesÂ¶

  • Ubuntu Server (18.04 or newer recommended)

  • Docker and Docker Compose installed

  • Sudo access

  • Domain name (optional but recommended)

Quick Production SetupÂ¶

# Create deployment directory
mkdir -p ~/deploy_hed
cd ~/deploy_hed

# Download deployment script
curl -fsSL -o deploy.sh https://raw.githubusercontent.com/hed-standard/hed-web/main/deploy/deploy.sh

# Make script executable
chmod +x deploy.sh

# Run deployment (replace with your domain or IP)
sudo ./deploy.sh main prod your-domain.com

Manual Docker SetupÂ¶

If you prefer manual setup or need customization:

  1. Clone and prepare:

git clone https://github.com/hed-standard/hed-web
cd hed-web/deploy

  1. Configure environment:

cp base_config.py config.py
# Edit config.py as needed

  1. Build and run:

docker build -t hedweb .
docker run -d -p 33000:80 --name hedweb-container hedweb

The application will be available on port 33000.

Reverse Proxy SetupÂ¶

For production deployments, youâ€™ll typically want to use a reverse proxy like Nginx or Apache.

Nginx ConfigurationÂ¶

Create /etc/nginx/sites-available/hedweb:

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name your-domain.com;

    location / {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:33000;
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;
        
        # Handle large file uploads
        client_max_body_size 100M;
    }
}

Enable the site:

sudo ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/hedweb /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/
sudo nginx -t
sudo systemctl reload nginx

SSL/TLS Setup with CertbotÂ¶

# Install Certbot
sudo apt install certbot python3-certbot-nginx

# Get SSL certificate
sudo certbot --nginx -d your-domain.com

# Verify auto-renewal
sudo certbot renew --dry-run

Configuration ReferenceÂ¶

Environment VariablesÂ¶

The application can be configured using environment variables:

Variable

Description

Default

Example

HED_WEB_HOST

Server host

127.0.0.1

0.0.0.0

HED_WEB_PORT

Server port

5000

8080

HED_WEB_DEBUG

Debug mode

False

True

HED_WEB_SECRET_KEY

Flask secret key

Generated

your-secret-key

Configuration File OptionsÂ¶

Edit config.py to customize:

# Basic settings
HOST = '127.0.0.1'
PORT = 5000
DEBUG = True

# Security
SECRET_KEY = 'your-secret-key-here'
WTF_CSRF_ENABLED = True

# Upload settings
MAX_CONTENT_LENGTH = 16 * 1024 * 1024  # 16MB max file size

# HED schema settings
HED_CACHE_FOLDER = '/tmp/hed_cache'
DEFAULT_HED_VERSION = '8.2.0'

TestingÂ¶

Running TestsÂ¶

Unit TestsÂ¶

python -m unittest discover -s tests/ -p 'test_*.py'

Service TestsÂ¶

python -m unittest discover -s services_tests/ -p 'test_*.py'

Note

You must have a running instance of the application to run service tests.

Run All TestsÂ¶

python -m unittest discover

Test with CoverageÂ¶

pip install coverage
python -m coverage run --source=hedweb -m unittest discover
python -m coverage report
python -m coverage html

The coverage HTML report will be available in htmlcov/index.html.

Test StructureÂ¶

tests/                  # Unit tests
â”œâ”€â”€ test_*.py
â””â”€â”€ data/              # Test data files

services_tests/        # Integration tests
â”œâ”€â”€ test_services_*.py
â””â”€â”€ data/              # Test data files

TroubleshootingÂ¶

Common IssuesÂ¶

Issue: ModuleNotFoundErrorÂ¶

Symptoms: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'hedweb'

Solution:

  1. Ensure virtual environment is activated

  2. Install requirements: pip install -r requirements.txt

  3. Check Python version: python --version (should be 3.10+)

Issue: Port Already in UseÂ¶

Symptoms: Address already in use error

Solution:

  1. Use a different port: hedweb --port 5001

  2. Or kill existing process:

    # Find process using port 5000
netstat -tulpn | grep :5000
# Kill process by PID
kill -9 <PID>

Issue: Permission Denied (Linux/macOS)Â¶

Symptoms: Permission errors when running commands

Solution:

  1. Check file permissions: ls -la

  2. Make scripts executable: chmod +x script_name.sh

  3. Use sudo only when necessary

Issue: Docker Container Wonâ€™t StartÂ¶

Symptoms: Container exits immediately or fails to start

Solution:

  1. Check logs: docker logs hedweb-container

  2. Verify port availability: netstat -tulpn | grep :33000

  3. Check configuration files

  4. Ensure Docker daemon is running

Getting Debug InformationÂ¶

Application LogsÂ¶

# Enable debug mode
export HED_WEB_DEBUG=True
hedweb --debug

System InformationÂ¶

# Python version
python --version

# Installed packages
pip list

# System info (Linux/macOS)
uname -a

# System info (Windows)
systeminfo

Performance OptimizationÂ¶

For DevelopmentÂ¶

  • Use --debug flag for auto-reload

  • Disable unnecessary features in config

  • Use local HED schemas when possible

For ProductionÂ¶

  • Set DEBUG = False in config

  • Use production WSGI server (gunicorn)

  • Enable caching

  • Use reverse proxy (Nginx/Apache)

  • Monitor resource usage

Getting HelpÂ¶

Documentation ResourcesÂ¶

  • API Documentation: API Reference

  • HED Standard: https://www.hedtags.org/

  • GitHub Repository: https://github.com/hed-standard/hed-web

Community SupportÂ¶

  • GitHub Issues: Report bugs or request features

  • Discussions: Ask questions in GitHub Discussions

  • Email: Contact the HED team for enterprise support

ContributingÂ¶

We welcome contributions! Please see:

  • CONTRIBUTING.md for development guidelines

  • CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md for community guidelines

  • Open issues for areas needing help

AppendixÂ¶

Command ReferenceÂ¶

Development CommandsÂ¶

# Start development server
hedweb --host 127.0.0.1 --port 5000 --debug

# Run tests
python -m unittest discover -s tests/ -p 'test_*.py'

# Build documentation
sphinx-build -b html docs docs/_build/html

# Install in development mode
pip install -e .

Production CommandsÂ¶

# Build Docker image
docker build -t hedweb .

# Run Docker container
docker run -d -p 33000:80 hedweb

# Check container status
docker ps

# View container logs
docker logs hedweb-container

File Structure OverviewÂ¶

hed-web/
â”œâ”€â”€ hedweb/                    # Main application package
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ __init__.py
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ app_factory.py        # Flask application factory
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ routes.py             # Web routes
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ ...                   # Other modules
â”œâ”€â”€ docs/                     # Documentation
â”œâ”€â”€ tests/                    # Unit tests
â”œâ”€â”€ services_tests/           # Integration tests
â”œâ”€â”€ deploy/                   # Deployment files
â”œâ”€â”€ requirements.txt          # Python dependencies
â”œâ”€â”€ config_template.py        # Configuration template
â””â”€â”€ setup.py                  # Package setup
